text: on Tuesday Phelps continue this chase of
Mark Spitz with his third gold medal and
world record in as many days but this
isn't a one-man show records are falling
faster than leaves and autumn in the
first three days of the nine-day
competition 10 Swimming World Records
have been set reasons why the swimmers
here are going so fast ranged from the
pools state of the art design to the
high-tech swimsuits notably the speedo
laser racer there may be some basis in
science to explain the suits advantage
it contains girdle like panels that
shape the body into a more streamlined
form and it contains virtually no seams
in order to reduce drag but whatever
physical advantage the suit may give the
swimmer if swimmers believe a certain
swimsuit will make them go fast chances
are good that it will an overlooked
reason for the fast times is the age of
the athletes great swimmers can now make
a living in their sport enabling them to
extend their careers well beyond their
college years consider the case of Don's
show Lander show Lander with four gold
medals in a single games retired after
appearing in his second Olympics he was
22 the poster boy for longevity is
Phelps as 4 x 100 freestyle relay may 32
year old jason lezak on monday he swam
the fastest 100 freestyle relay split of
all time as the Americans edged the
french team and shattered the world
record on tuesday 25 year old Aaron
Pierce all lowered his own world record
in the hundred backstroke on the way to
winning the gold in the women's race
twenty-four-year-old kirstie coventry of
Zimbabwe who had lowered the world
record the day before one silver what
does this say maybe it's not about the
pool but the ever increasing pool of
available athletes in many countries who
are pushing the envelope here this is
Karen Kraus of the New York Times
reporting from Beijing
